metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: The ng-model directive binds the value of HTML controls (input, select, textarea) to application data.
content.html: The ng-model directive binds the value of HTML controls (input, select, textarea) to application data.

content.text: With the ng-model directive you can bind the value of an input field to a variable created in AngularJS.
content.html: With the ng-model directive you can bind the value of an input field to a variable created in AngularJS.

content.code: Name:
content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">
  Name: <input ng-model="name">
</div>

<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
  $scope.name = "John Doe";
});
</script>

content.text: The binding goes both ways. If the user changes the value inside the input field, the AngularJS property will also change its value:
content.html: The binding goes both ways. If the user changes the value inside the input field, the AngularJS property will also change its value:

content.code_html:
<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">
  Name: <input ng-model="name">
  <h1>You entered: {{name}}</h1>
</div>

content.text: The ng-model directive can provide type validation for application data (number, e-mail, required):
content.html: The ng-model directive can provide type validation for application data (number, e-mail, required):

content.code: Email:   Not a valid e-mail address
content.code_html:
<form ng-app="" name="myForm">
  Email:
  <input type="email" name="myAddress" ng-model="text">
  <span ng-show="myForm.myAddress.$error.email">Not a valid e-mail address</span>
</form>

content.text: In the example above, the span will be displayed only if the expression in the ng-show attribute returns true .
content.html: In the example above, the span will be displayed only if the expression in the ng-show attribute returns true.

content.text: If the property in the ng-model attribute does not exist, AngularJS will create one for you.
content.html: If the property in the ng-model attribute does not exist, AngularJS will create one for you.

content.text: The ng-model directive can provide status for application data (valid, dirty, touched, error):
content.html: The ng-model directive can provide status for application data (valid, dirty, touched, error):

content.code:
Email:      

Status

  {{myForm.myAddress.$valid}}   {{myForm.myAddress.$dirty}}   {{myForm.myAddress.$touched}}
content.code_html:
<form ng-app="" name="myForm" ng-init="myText = 'post@myweb.com'">
  Email:
  <input type="email" name="myAddress" ng-model="myText" required>
  <h1>Status</h1>
  {{myForm.myAddress.$valid}}
  {{myForm.myAddress.$dirty}}
  {{myForm.myAddress.$touched}}
</form>

content.text: The ng-model directive provides CSS classes for HTML elements, depending on their status:
content.html: The ng-model directive provides CSS classes for HTML elements, depending on their status:

content.code_html:
<style>
input.ng-invalid {
  background-color: lightblue;
}
</style>
<body>

<form ng-app="" name="myForm">
  Enter your name:
  <input name="myName" ng-model="myText" required>
</form>

content.text: The ng-model directive adds/removes the following classes, according to the status of the form field:
content.html: The ng-model directive adds/removes the following classes, according to the status of the form field:
